channel.title: OnOptions
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from OnOptions, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: How I turned ADHD and anxiety into a successful wellness company
item.description: I started building Simple in 2019 with a vision that one day, a digital product could help people fix their health as effectively as a human. Five yea...

item.title: Tomorrow, the MTA will stop selling MetroCards. Good riddance
item.description: My bus rolls into Port Authority. I’ve got 10 minutes to get across town for my first meeting. I sprint down the escalator, run through droves of peop...

item.title: How to Emphasize Different Benefits and Attract the Best Job Candidates
item.description: An Indeed analysis of job searches found the perks employees want differ significantly by age and gender.

item.title: Simon Sinek says not to worry about salaries during a job interview. Instead, ‘choose the job based on who you’re going to work for’
item.description: “Yes, I made less money than all of my friends in the short term,” Sinek said. But “I got an education and care from somebody who took me under their ...

item.title: A vicious cycle beats a virtuous one: How Warren Buffett’s Geico fell behind Progressive in the auto insurance race
item.description: While Geico was investing in marketing and neglecting IT, its rival Progressive was investing in technology and gaining market share.

item.title: The Surprising Advertising Strategy AI Companies Are Investing in to Stand Out
item.description: The AI race may be digital, but the frontlines of its marketing wars are in the real world.

item.title: You can’t reach a goal without a plan
item.description: I’ve done it, you’ve done it, we’ve all done it. With the best of intentions, we set big goals for our future: get a work promotion, lose 20 pounds, r...

item.title: Warren Buffett’s blind spot: Did the digital economy leave him behind?
item.description: Warren Buffett posted pedestrian investment returns over the last years of his career, due largely to a failure to grasp the potential of Big Tech.

item.title: AI adoption at scale is hard. Just look at India, which processes about 20 billion transactions every month
item.description: The most valuable AI systems will not look dramatic. They will look ordinary. They will fade into routine decisions and familiar processes.

item.title: The Future of AI in 2026: Trends and Strategies You Need to Win
item.description: To understand where we’re headed, it helps to break the AI landscape into four categories.

item.title: The 5 weirdest brand partnerships from 2025 prove collabs have lost the plot
item.description: Ketchup-inspired luggage. Soap based on the characters from Stranger Things . A hot sauce energy drink. These are just a few of the brand collaboratio...

item.title: I Hope Netflix Knows a Guy Who Knows a Guy
item.description: How do we get business leaders to act in their own best interests, even as their greed and indifference keeps them from doing anything?

item.title: 7 CEOs share their New Year’s resolutions

item.title: Google Co-founder Sergey Brin’s Unretirement Is a Lesson for the Rest of Us
item.description: The tech founder’s return to full-time work is a reminder that even billions can’t guarantee a happy retirement if you don’t also do this.

item.title: Why Singapore is the only Southeast Asian country in Pax Silica, the U.S.’s new AI ‘inner circle’
